column1: A solar cell or photovoltaic cell is a device that converts light energy into electrical energy. Sometimes the term solar cell is reserved for devices intended specifically to capture energy from sunlight
column2: while the term photovoltaic cell is used when the light source is unspecified. The device needs to fulfill only two functions: photogeneration of charge carriers (electrons and electron holes) in a light-absorbing material
column3: and separation of the charge carriers to a conductive contact that will transmit the electricity. This conversion is called the photovoltaic effect
column4: and the field related to solar cells is known as photovoltaics. Solar cells have many apps. They have long been used in situations where electrical power from the grid is unavailable
column5: such as in remote area power systems
column8: e.g. handheld calculators or wrist watches
column9: remote radiotelephones and water pumping applications. More recently
column10: they are starting to be used in assemblies of solar modules connected to the electricity grid through an inverter
column11: often in combination with net metering.
